docs.lead_paragraph: STATE HIGHWAY 84 parallels the Mississippi River as it cuts through northwestern Illinois and the flat cornfields north of Cordova. The land along the road looks untouched by the 20th century except for the Rock Island Nuclear Power Station, which squats heavily on the ice-crusted river bank amid a spider's web of transmission lines. Every workday Rick Risdal, 29, pedaled his bicycle past the plant and turned off the two-lane blacktop into the driveway of the Xylen Company, a far less imposing compound crowded with pungent heaps of shredded tree bark, large sheds and twin rows of parked tractor-trailer trucks.

headline.main: One Day's Death Toll on the Job

docs.abstract: US Bureau of Labor Statistics says average of 17 people die daily in US because of the work they do; that amounted to 6,210 job-related deaths in 1995, almost exactly the number (6,217) recorded in 1992, the year the bureau its conducted its first 50-state census of work fatalities; figure covers accidents, homicides and suicides on the job, but not deaths from natural causes; graphs; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: IF you have any money left after the holidays, there is no shortage of advice on how to invest it. The January issues of the personal-finance magazines -- along with three special year-end issues -- are loaded with prognostications and lists of stock picks for 1997. It's fascinating that so few stocks show up on more than one list. Occasionally, American Express, Walt Disney or a biotechnology company appears twice, but the vast majority do not. Presumably, different stock pickers are using different research and analytical criteria, but the average reader might be forgiven for suspecting that the experts don't have a clue. And a good record in this surging market hasn't exactly been mission impossible.

headline.main: The Predictions: Will the Real 1997 Please Stand Up?

docs.abstract: January issues of personal-finance magazines are loaded with prognostications and lists of stock picks for 1997; magazines are nervously bullish on stocks for 1997; most predict correction in first half, followed by a rebound; some analysts see Dow Jones industrial average hitting 9,000 or 10,000 in coming years; photos (L)/

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Doctor, What's the Prognosis? Crisis in Canada'' (news article, Dec. 15) misdiagnoses the health-care problems in Canada. Canada is simply one of many countries straining to maintain a universal health insurance program at a price tag near 10 percent of its gross domestic product. Physician concerns about eroding quality of care (exaggerated in your article) are chronic symptoms of Canada's success, not symptoms of its failure.

headline.kicker: Don't Distort Flaws In Canada Health Care

docs.abstract: Dr Steven Jay Katz letter says Dec 15 article misdiagnoses health-care problems in Canada; says Canadian experience shows that balancing health-care budget requires painful decisions on allocating resources
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Doctor, What's the Prognosis? Crisis in Canada'' (news article, Dec. 15) misdiagnoses the health-care problems in Canada. Canada is simply one of many countries straining to maintain a universal health insurance program at a price...

docs.lead_paragraph: If a featherbedding Olympics were ever held, the gold medal might go to the New York City painters' union, with its rule banning the use of paint rollers wider than 9 inches and another requiring afternoon coffee breaks even though the workday ends at 3:30. Then there are the rules requiring that painters receive double pay for any work exceeding seven hours a day, and a full day's pay even if they come for just 30 minutes to touch up a ceiling.

headline.main: To Save Jobs, Painters' Union Agrees to Relax Its Rules

docs.abstract: New York City branch of International Brotherhood of Painters and Allied Trades decides to jettison its most restrictive work rules in effort to stem loss of work to non-union painters (M)

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: INTERNATIONAL BROTHERHOOD OF PAINTERS AND ALLIED TRADES

docs.lead_paragraph: Tommy Wilmette slouches against a doorjamb with coiled reptilian calm, his hooded eyes searching for signs of weakness in his lumbering prey. A specialist in hostile takeovers, Wilmette has set his sights on a new victim: Chicago Hope Hospital. ''You're too expensive; your surgeries aren't cost-effective,'' he tells one of the hospital's finest doctors, who also happens to be his ex-wife. ''In fact, you're exactly the kind of doctor I'll be eliminating when we downsize.'' Just across town and a couple of prime-time evenings later, paramedics wheel a new patient into County General Hospital's emergency room, rattling off staccato symptoms: ''Two-day-old male infant, full-term vaginal delivery, found cyanotic in his crib, resp 50, heart rate 160.''

headline.main: TV's Powerful Doctor Shows vs. the H.M.O.

docs.abstract: Article on television programs ER and Chicago Hope holds both shows have deep distrust, if not contempt, for the business of medicine; says characters in both shows battle health maintenance organizations and debate politicians over budget cuts; photos (L)
